docs.text: The Loom: Fate's Instrument See also World Summary , Metaphysics , Magic Systems , Society , Governance , Planetary , and Conlang . Overview The Loom is the distributed network of devices, rituals, and institutions that read, record, and predict fate in Hálcova. It is not a single machine but a system—part arcane technology, part religious practice, part bureaucratic apparatus. More importantly: The Loom may be a point of contact with Fate itself. Whether Fate is an Elsewhere entity, a collection of entities, or something stranger is a matter of fierce theological debate. What's undeniable is that The Loom works . Its predictions are accurate far beyond statistical chance. And something answers when the Loom-Keepers perform their divinations. What The Loom Is The Physical Infrastructure Loom-Nodes Distributed across Hálcova, Loom-Nodes are the physical anchors of the system: Major Nodes : Large installations in capital cities and religious centers. Cathedral-sized complexes housing pattern-engines, archives, and ritual spaces. Staffed by hundreds of Loom-Keepers. Minor Nodes : Town-level facilities. Smaller pattern-engines, local registries, drawing chambers. Staffed by licensed practitioners and temple appointees. Mobile Nodes : Portable equipment for frontier regions, military operations, and emergency readings. Less accurate but functional. Private Nodes : Illegal or gray-market installations operated by wealthy individuals, corporations, and criminal organizations. Quality varies wildly. The Pattern-Engines At the heart of each Node is a pattern-engine—a device that: Records Sórscad data from drawings Performs predictive calculations Communicates with other Nodes (major ones only) Interfaces with... something. The source of The Loom's impossible accuracy. Pattern-engines are part clockwork, part alchemical apparatus, part something that defies categorization. Their construction is a closely guarded secret. Their fuel is Pattern Residue—the same substance that maintains echo anchors. The Institutional Structure The Loom-Keepers A guild-priesthood that operates The Loom. They are: Trained in pattern-reading, engine operation, and ritual practice Licensed by both religious and civil authorities Bound by oaths that constrain their use of Loom-knowledge Organized hierarchically from apprentices to High Weavers Loom-Keepers occupy an ambiguous social position. They're essential to Governance , commerce, and religion. They're also viewed with suspicion—people who know too much about everyone else's fate. The Registry The accumulated database of all Sórscad patterns ever drawn. Stored in: Physical archives (paper, metal plates, encoded materials) Pattern-engine memory (poorly understood how this works) Distributed across major Nodes with varying levels of completeness The Registry is legally protected, politically contested, and practically impossible to fully secure. Pattern-theft, registry-manipulation, and archive-raids are all documented crimes. Calculation Houses Institutions using Loom data: actuarial houses, credit temples, merchant guilds , legal colleges, military orders. License Loom access for insurance, lending, employment, sentencing, recruitment. What The Loom Does Pattern recording: Sórscad drawn via ritual, captured, recorded, indexed, transmitted. Prediction: life-arc probabilities, decision tendencies, risk profiles, compatibility assessments. Deviation detection: minor, significant, anomalous—can indicate error, environment, manipulation, or theologically troubling events. The Source: Fate as Entity Orthodox: Loom reads the Weaver's will. Heterodox: Loom's accuracy may come from Elsewhere entities, pacts, or Pattern Residue as payment. Loom-Keepers know something answers rituals but don't know what it is. The Accuracy Problem Why does it work? Fate is real, Loom reads it; Loom creates what it predicts; Elsewhere entities arrange outcomes; combination. Bias: Loom reflects historical power structures, discrimination, feedback loops. Pattern Residue: The Fuel Energy released when patterns dissolve at death. Natural sources: any death, more from trauma/heavy patterns. Manufactured: executions, blood-sport, war, plague, livestock. Used for Loom, core binding, alchemy, magitech. Economy: peace is expensive, war is profitable, disaster is opportunity. Regional Distribution Core regions: dense Loom coverage, strong Orthodoxy, pattern-privileged. Peripheral: sparse coverage, mixed religion, deviation common. Frontier: minimal Loom, heterodox, unregistered. Contested: Loom is political battleground. Attitudes Toward The Loom Universal acceptance of accuracy; disagreement about why. Faithful (divine will), pragmatists (useful), reformers (misused), skeptics (self-fulfilling), conspiracists (controlled). Terminology Reference Term Meaning The Loom Fate-prediction and pattern-tracking system Loom-Node Physical installation Pattern-Engine Device for recording/calculating Loom-Keeper Licensed operator High Weaver Senior rank The Registry Database of Sórscad patterns The Weaver Divine source Pattern Residue Energy from pattern dissolution Deviation Divergence from prediction The Attendance Entity answering rituals Further documentation needed on: Pattern-engine construction, Loom-Keeper training, Registry security, Node communication, Attendance behavior. docs.text: Hálcova: Political Philosophy in a Fate-Real World See also World Summary , Metaphysics , Magic Systems , Fate System , Society , Planetary , and Conlang . The Fundamental Problem Every political philosophy on Earth assumes a baseline: people are created equal, or they aren't, but either way you can't prove it by reading their metaphysical signature at birth. Hálcova doesn't have that luxury. The Sórscad exists. It's readable. It predicts outcomes with uncomfortable accuracy. This breaks political philosophy at its foundations and forces reconstruction from first principles. The Questions That Matter What Does "Equality" Mean? On Earth : Equality typically means equal moral worth, equal rights, equal standing before the law—regardless of observable differences in capability or circumstance. On Hálcova : Observable differences include fate itself . The Loom can tell you, with measurable accuracy, whether this person will contribute to society or drain it, create value or destroy it, help or harm. The Problem : If equality means "treat everyone the same regardless of pattern," you're ignoring real information. A lender who ignores pattern when making loans will be outcompeted by one who doesn't. An employer who ignores pattern will hire worse workers. The system punishes equality. If equality means "treat everyone according to their pattern," you've created a caste system justified by prophecy. Pattern becomes destiny not because fate is fixed, but because everyone acts as if it is. Possible Positions : Pattern Realism : Patterns are real, differences are real, and pretending otherwise is foolish. Equality is a comfortable lie. Governance should optimize for outcomes, which means differential treatment. Pattern Skepticism : Patterns predict partly because people believe them. True equality requires ignoring patterns—which is costly but morally necessary. Someone has to pay the cost of treating people as if they had equal worth. Pattern Complexity : Equality doesn't mean "same treatment." It means "equal consideration of interests." A constrained pattern doesn't mean someone deserves less consideration—it means they need different support. Consent On Hálcova, the Loom knows whether you'll consent before you do. Consent is complicated by prediction, manipulation, and pattern constraints. Positions: experienced, structural, predictive, skepticism. Legitimacy Authority may be legitimized by pattern, Loom-sanction, prediction, or pragmatic success. Regional theories: Heartlands (theocratic), Shattered Reaches (contract), Middle Waters (contested), Vent Lands (expertise), Far Shelf (autonomy). Legal Frameworks Intent and prediction: pattern-predictive policing, pattern-blind law, pattern-weighted sentencing, pattern as mitigating factor. Actual legal variation by region. Criminal justice intersects with residue production; execution rates and residue demand are linked. Property and Pattern Inheritance, contracts, innovation, and property rights are shaped by pattern. Positions: libertarian, distributive, communitarian, skeptic. Inter-Regional Politics Trade web: residue, food, labor flows. Power balance: Heartlands (military), Shattered Reaches (navy), Vent Lands (fortress), Middle Waters (contested), Far Shelf (space). Warden Order Transnational authority, legal presence varies by region, resistance and political function. Summary Table Question Orthodox (Heartlands) Contractarian (Reaches) Colonial (Middle Waters) Technocratic (Vents) Autonomist (Far Shelf) Equality Pattern determines worth Formal equality despite pattern Depends who's asking Expertise determines worth Pattern oppresses; resist Justice Pattern-deviation is crime Actions matter, not patterns Power determines Guild judgment Community decides Consent Pattern includes consent Real but fragile Manufactured Irrelevant to competence Essential to legitimacy Authority Divine pattern-mandate Agreement of governed Whoever wins Those who can Those who defend Further documentation needed on: Legal codes by region, treaties, Warden jurisdiction, pattern-discrimination case law, succession crises. docs.text: The Five Arts of Hálcova See also World Summary , Metaphysics , Fate System , Society , Governance , Planetary , and Conlang . A Comprehensive Guide to the Magic Systems Overview In Hálcova, power is never free. Every magical tradition operates on the same fundamental truth: you must spend something real to gain something real. There are no shortcuts, no loopholes, no clever tricks that let you escape the cost. The universe keeps ledgers, and it always collects. The five magical traditions—collectively called the Five Arts—each represent a different answer to the question: What are you willing to pay? Art What You Spend What You Get What It Costs You Core Binding The dead Echoes of the deceased Your sense of self (bleed corruption) Flesh Shaping Blood and meat Constructed servants Your body and humanity Pact Summoning Your soul Elsewhere entities Your autonomy and existence Fate Threading Your future Versions of yourself Your potential and becoming Colony Summoning Corpses and biomass Fungal constructs Your identity and bodily sovereignty Each Art is a transaction. Each transaction has fine print. Nobody reads the fine print until it's too late. Category One: Core Binding The Art of Holding the Dead Fundamental Principle When a living thing dies, something remains. Not a ghost, not a spirit—something more fundamental. The core is the imprint of what a creature was: its patterns, its memories, its essence compressed into something that can be harvested, stored, and summoned. Core Binding is the practice of trapping these cores in physical anchors and calling them forth as echoes —manifestations of the dead that walk, speak, and act as they did in life. The horror: the echoes don't know they're dead. They think they're still alive, still themselves. They might ask about family members who've moved on, wonder why the world has changed, try to go home to houses that no longer exist. You know. They don't. That's the relationship. The Core Explore Related Topics World Summary Metaphysics Fate System Society Governance Planetary Conlang What It Is The core is harvestable from anything that dies. Not just humans—animals, beasts, monsters, anything with sufficient complexity to leave an imprint. The core contains enough of the original to function: walk, fight, remember fragments, express personality. But it's incomplete. A copy of a copy. The full person is gone; what remains is an echo that doesn't know it's an echo. Harvesting Cores must be harvested at or shortly after death. The process varies by tradition and culture, but the essence is the same: you extract the core before it dissipates and bind it to a physical anchor. See Metaphysics . Skilled harvesters can sense cores. They know when one is strong (a person who died with purpose, with unfinished business, with intensity) and when one is weak (peaceful deaths, accepted endings, lives that felt complete). The strongest cores come from: - Violent deaths - Deaths with unfinished purpose - Deaths accompanied by intense emotion - Deaths that the dying refused to accept The weakest cores come from: - Peaceful passings - Deaths accepted and prepared for - Lives that felt complete Core Binding (Echo Binding) Anchors: Physical objects housing bound echoes—figurines, tiles, metal plates, bone carvings, jewelry. The anchor must depict the bound echo, either by natural manifestation or artistic creation. Binders carry as many anchors as they can transport; activation summons echoes, but too many cause resonance interference and physical drain. Upkeep: Echoes require a consumable resource to remain coherent. Resource economy includes harvesters, refiners, merchants, smugglers, and black markets. See Society . Consumption rates vary by echo complexity and awareness. Quality matters—adulterated, counterfeited, aged, or fresh. Decay: Echo bleed causes phantom sensations, behavioral drift, and memory intrusion. Awareness accelerates decay. Old binders become patchworks of their echoes. Release: Possible but rare—money, spite, revenge, nostalgia, love, exhaustion. Most binders hold on long past reason. Opposition: Family, religious/philosophical groups, former binders, governments. The living object; the echoes don't know they're dead. Economy: Cores are commodities. Poachers, assassins, scavengers, harvesters, brokers, appraisers, storage facilities. Wars produce inventory. Anomalies: Extracting a core from the living creates disturbing, unstable anomalies. Terminology: To be developed in conlang—core, binding, echo, anchor, binder, resource, bleed. Category Two: Flesh Shaping The Art of Constructing Life Fundamental Principle Life is raw potential, waiting for the right conditions to be realized. Flesh Shaping is the art of taking this potential and giving it form. By sacrificing your own blood and meat, you can shape and animate matter, creating homunculi—servants that carry out your will. The horror: each homunculus is a patchwork of materials, held together by your blood and will. They are not alive in the traditional sense; they do not grow, reproduce, or truly think. They are reflections of your own body and mind, distorted and incomplete. The Process Materials Homunculi can be made from any combination of materials: flesh, bone, clay, metal, wax, leather. The more complex the desired homunculus, the more materials and blood are required. The Spark The spark of life is your own blood, infused with your will and intent. It is what animates the homunculus, giving it the semblance of life. Without this spark, the materials remain inert, mere shapes without purpose or direction. Tethering and Conjuring Once the homunculus is formed, it must be tethered to you, its creator. This tether is a lifeline, linking the homunculus to your own life force. As long as the tether remains intact, the homunculus will obey your commands and act as your servant. However, the tether is also a vulnerability. If the homunculus is destroyed, the shock can bleed into you, causing physical and spiritual harm. Moreover, the more homunculi you have active, the weaker each tether becomes, and the greater the strain on your own body and mind. Further documentation needed on: Transaction costs, horror elements, additional systems, terminology in conlang.

Release: Possible but rare—money, spite, revenge, nostalgia, love, exhaustion. Most binders hold on long past reason. Opposition: Family, religious/philosophical groups, former binders, governments. The living object; the echoes don't know they're dead. Economy: Cores are commodities. Poachers, assassins, scavengers, harvesters, brokers, appraisers, storage facilities. Wars produce inventory. Anomalies: Extracting a core from the living creates disturbing, unstable anomalies. Terminology: To be developed in conlang—core, binding, echo, anchor, binder, resource, bleed.
docs.title: Core Binding (Echo Binding)

docs.text: Life is raw potential, waiting for the right conditions to be realized. Flesh Shaping is the art of taking this potential and giving it form. By sacrificing your own blood and meat, you can shape and animate matter, creating homunculi—servants that carry out your will. The horror: each homunculus is a patchwork of materials, held together by your blood and will. They are not alive in the traditional sense; they do not grow, reproduce, or truly think. They are reflections of your own body and mind, distorted and incomplete.
docs.title: Fundamental Principle

docs.text: Materials Homunculi can be made from any combination of materials: flesh, bone, clay, metal, wax, leather. The more complex the desired homunculus, the more materials and blood are required. The Spark The spark of life is your own blood, infused with your will and intent. It is what animates the homunculus, giving it the semblance of life. Without this spark, the materials remain inert, mere shapes without purpose or direction. Tethering and Conjuring Once the homunculus is formed, it must be tethered to you, its creator. This tether is a lifeline, linking the homunculus to your own life force. As long as the tether remains intact, the homunculus will obey your commands and act as your servant. However, the tether is also a vulnerability. If the homunculus is destroyed, the shock can bleed into you, causing physical and spiritual harm. Moreover, the more homunculi you have active, the weaker each tether becomes, and the greater the strain on your own body and mind. docs.text: Hálcova isn't a world with an economy. Hálcova is an economy. The metaphysical substrate of reality operates on the same principles that govern markets, decisions, and resource allocation. This isn't metaphor—it's the literal structure of how existence functions here. See also World Summary , Magic Systems , Fate System , Society , Governance , Planetary , and Conlang . Physics has transaction costs. Identity is a balance sheet. Time is currency with variable exchange rates. Death is a market event. The Elsewhere is a competing market. Economic Principles Made Literal Opportunity Cost (Fate Threading): Every choice forecloses alternatives. The cost of any action is the value of the best alternative you didn't take. How It Manifests : When a Fate Threader pulls a version of themselves from an unmade choice, they're not accessing a parallel universe. They're harvesting the opportunity cost itself . The future they didn't choose had value—stored potential—and they're cashing it out. But opportunity costs aren't free-floating. They're attached to you . When you harvest one: - Gain the capability/knowledge/resource from that path - Permanently close that path (it's been spent) - Reduce your total remaining "decision space" The Horror : Your life starts with a vast decision tree of possible futures. Each extraction shrinks it. Extract enough, and you've narrowed your remaining possibilities to a single track. You become deterministic—not because fate is fixed, but because you've spent all your alternatives. The Economic Parallel : This is exactly how real opportunity costs work. Every career choice, relationship, investment closes doors. Hálcova just makes the ledger visible and the withdrawals explicit. Sunk Cost Fallacy (Core Binding): People irrationally weigh costs already paid when making current decisions, even though those costs can't be recovered. How It Manifests : Core Binding creates echoes—remnants of the dead bound to anchors. The binder invests Pattern Residue, time, and pieces of their own identity to maintain the binding. See Magic Systems . The fallacy manifests when: - The echo becomes corrupted or hostile - The echo's information becomes outdated - The echo's presence damages the binder's relationships Rationally, the binder should release the echo. But they've invested so much. The echo contains memories of their dead spouse, or crucial knowledge from a lost mentor, or evidence of a crime. The binder thinks: "I've already paid for this. I can't waste that investment." The Horror : Binders hold onto echoes past all rational justification. The echo of your mother starts forgetting who you are, starts confusing you with your dead sibling, starts asking why you killed her. You should let her go. But you've spent fifteen years maintaining this binding. Surely another year will fix it. Another decade. The sunk cost compounds. Explore Related Topics World Summary Magic Systems Fate System Society Governance Planetary Conlang The Structural Element : The magic system rewards sunk cost thinking. Older bindings are stronger, more coherent, more useful—if you can hold on long enough. This creates genuine uncertainty about whether continuing is irrational or just requires patience. The fallacy becomes indistinguishable from reasonable strategy. Moral Hazard (Pact Summoning): When someone is insulated from the consequences of their actions, they take greater risks. The Principle : Pact Summoning allows you to substitute others' souls for your own in paying entity costs. This creates classic moral hazard: - You get the power without the personal cost - Others pay the price, often without their consent - Incentives for caution or restraint are externalized How It Manifests : Entities design pacts to encourage substitution, feeding on more souls. Society creates markets for "willing" substitutes, insurance pools, and political systems that externalize pact costs onto underclasses. The system optimizes for maximum soul consumption. The Horror : The more powerful the binder, the greater the temptation to exploit this moral hazard. Entire communities can be sacrificed for the ambitions of a few. The fabric of society erodes as individuals act purely in their self-interest, insulated from the consequences. Game Theory Made Literal Prisoner's Dilemma: Individually rational choices produce collectively irrational outcomes. Entities create substitution deals so accepting is rational, but coordinated refusal would be better. Information asymmetry prevents coordination. The entity harvests not just souls but the coordination failure itself. Psychological Principles Made Literal Cognitive Dissonance: Wardens rationalize themselves into true belief through dissonance reduction. The Attunement process maximizes sacrifice and belief intensification. Doubt is experienced as weakness and suppressed. Philosophical Frameworks Made Literal Determinism vs. Free Will: The Loom predicts choices but doesn't make them. Compatibilist, hard determinist, libertarian, and pragmatist readings all coexist. Your position on free will becomes part of your pattern. The Elsewhere as Competing Economic System The Elsewhere isn't a place, but an alternative transaction framework. Scarcity, exchange, debt, and obligation operate differently. Factions represent economic philosophies: Accountants (debt), Hungry (consumption), Architects (order), Mirrors (observation), Absent (negation). The Loom as Attention Economy The Loom may allocate attention, not just predict fate. Reality requires observation to stabilize. The Attendance is the observer, and attention is finite. Getting the Loom's attention means determination, not protection. Summary: The Spine Hálcova's metaphysical structure rests on: # Principle Primary Expression Horror 1 Opportunity Cost Fate Threading Spending your own possibilities 2 Sunk Cost Fallacy Core Binding Can't let go of the dead 3 Moral Hazard Pact Summoning Others pay your price 4 Asymmetric Information The Loom They know you better than you 5 Principal-Agent Problem Warden Order Enforcers serve themselves 6 Externalities Residue Economy Death's costs are socialized 7 Hyperbolic Discounting Colony Hosting The colony waits 8 Prisoner's Dilemma Substitution Market Coordination failure as harvest 9 Tragedy of Commons Residue Harvesting Importing death from elsewhere 10 Mechanism Design The Loom's Origin Someone built this trap 11 Cognitive Dissonance Warden Attunement Believing because you sacrificed 12 Prospect Theory Pattern Gambling Predictions create reference points 13 Attribution Error Pattern Essentialism Character vs. circumstance 14 Determinism/Free Will Core Tension Unfalsifiable positions 15 Ship of Theseus Identity Erosion No fact about continuity 16 Experience Machine Elsewhere Temptation Simulation vs. reality These aren't metaphors or themes. They're the actual mechanisms by which reality operates. Economic theory is physics. Game theory is chemistry. Psychology is biology. docs.text: Hálcova: Geography and Continental Structure See also World Summary , Metaphysics , Magic Systems , Fate System , Society , Governance , and Conlang . Overview Hálcova's landmasses are arranged around the habitable equatorial band, with two major continents and three significant landmasses forming five distinct regions. The geography tells a story—the Heartlands and Shattered Reaches were once a single continent, torn apart by some ancient catastrophe. The rift that separated them became the Narrow Sea. The Shattered Heartlands Theory The Evidence Looking at the coastlines, the relationship is obvious: - The ragged eastern coast of the Greater Continent matches the western edge of the Shattered Reaches - Rock formations, mineral deposits, and fossil-equivalents continue across the gap - The Narrow Sea is a flooded rift valley, not a true ocean basin - Ancient ruins exist on both sides with matching architectural styles The Heartlands Spine of the continent, river valleys, southern coast, northern edge. Orthodox faith, Loom integration, trade networks . Specific nations to be developed. The Shattered Reaches Fragmented island-continent, matching coast, interior highlands, fracture zone, island chains. Maritime character, city-states, merchant leagues. The Middle Waters Volcanic archipelago, caldera, reef systems, thermal vents. Warmest region, contested territory, colony cults, religious diversity. The Vent Lands Continental fragment, volcanic activity, fire range, thermal valleys, steam fields, sulfur flats. Geothermal independence, trade federation, fleshwright guilds. The Far Shelf Large, flat, cold continent, southern ice edge, mineral ranges, tundra. Frontier character, indigenous confederacies, religious heterodoxy. The Seas Explore Related Topics World Summary Metaphysics Magic Systems Fate System Society Governance Conlang Narrow Sea (rift valley), Central Ocean (thermal loop), Vent Strait (geothermal channel), Far Water (cold crossing), Bitter Crossing (polar route). The Polar Regions Northern Cap (The Wound): Elsewhere connection, Köd bleed, ancient ruins. Southern Cap (The Prison): containment, engineered cold, ancient structures. Expeditions find evidence of contact and imprisonment. Ocean Currents: The Great Thermal Loop Surface currents (warm), regional branches, deep currents (cold), seasonal variations. docs.text: Pattern Arbitrage See also World Summary , Metaphysics , Magic Systems , Fate System , Governance , Planetary , and Conlang . Fate Futures Financial instruments that pay out based on whether predictions come true: "If subject achieves predicted career trajectory by age 30, contract pays X" "If subject dies by predicted cause within predicted window, contract pays Y" "If subject deviates significantly from pattern, contract is void" Who Trades These Insurance companies (hedging their risk assessments) Investment houses (speculating on populations) Criminal organizations (betting on specific outcomes they can influence) Governments (managing demographic predictions) Economics and Class in Hálcova Overview Economics in Hálcova cannot be separated from fate. The Sórscad pattern determines access to credit, employment, insurance, and opportunity. Pattern Residue—the energy of dissolving fates—fuels magic and industry. Death is literally productive. This creates an economy where some people are worth more dead than alive, where peace is expensive, and where the institutions that predict your future have financial stakes in that prediction coming true. The Fate Market Pattern as Asset Your Sórscad is not just identity—it's capital. Pattern-Weight Some patterns are "heavier" than others: - More fate-significance - More likely to impact events - More valuable as Pattern Residue when released Heavy patterns belong to: Explore Related Topics World Summary Metaphysics Magic Systems Fate System Governance Planetary Conlang Those born into consequential circumstances Those whose choices ripple outward Those predicted for significant outcomes (positive or negative) Light patterns belong to: - Those born into marginal circumstances - Those whose choices affect few others - Those predicted for unremarkable outcomes The Market Implications Heavy patterns command higher prices in substitution deals (Pact Summoning) Heavy patterns produce more valuable Residue upon death Heavy patterns are worth more to The Loom (more data value) Heavy patterns are targets for various exploitation This creates a hierarchy: some lives have more market value than others, calculated and priced. Pattern Speculation Fate Futures Financial instruments that pay out based on whether predictions come true: "If subject achieves predicted career trajectory by age 30, contract pays X" "If subject dies by predicted cause within predicted window, contract pays Y" "If subject deviates significantly from pattern, contract is void" Who Trades These Insurance companies (hedging their risk assessments) Investment houses (speculating on populations) Criminal organizations (betting on specific outcomes they can influence) Governments (managing demographic predictions) Arbitrage Patterns are mispriced; arbitrageurs invest in undervalued people and profit when they outperform predictions. Legal but morally ambiguous. Credit and Debt Pattern-based lending: interest rates, collateral, debt spirals. Poor borrowers pledge themselves—residue rights, pact-substitution, echo-indenture. Pact summoning functions like supernatural credit; substitution markets exist for souls. Employment and Opportunity Pattern-gated careers, pattern families and stereotypes, labor markets, wage differentials. Pattern segregation channels people into industries; wage gaps are legal and documented. Pattern Residue Economy Produced at death, concentrated at battlefields, plagues, executions. Demand creates incentives for war, plague, capital punishment. Residue trade: harvesting, refining, distribution, pricing. Magitech sector depends on residue; industries form political blocs. Class Structure Pattern-privileged: favorable patterns, success, low rates, good jobs. Pattern-constrained: unfavorable patterns, struggle, high rates, bad jobs. Pattern-illegible: practitioners, unpredictable, form own communities. Industrial Magitech Sector Residue-powered technology: pattern-engines, communication, transportation, manufacturing, weapons. Labor in magitech: exposure effects, psychological/social impact, pattern-constrained workers. Underground Economy Illegal trade: unregistered cores, substitution services, pattern data, unlicensed binding, black-market homunculi, infection services, fate-fraud, deviation assistance. Criminal organizations structured by pattern-family. The Common Person Daily life: employment, credit, housing, healthcare, family. Coping strategies: acceptance, hustle, escape, resistance. docs.text: Updated Overview Hálcova (HAHL-ko-vah) — "The Death-Between" — is a dark fantasy ice world orbiting an orange dwarf star. Every person carries a Sórscad , a five-part fate pattern that determines who they are and what they'll become. Something answers when this pattern is read. That something may be divine, may be Elsewhere, may be both. Nobody knows for certain. The world runs on death. Pattern Residue — the energy released when fates dissolve — fuels Magic Systems , industry, and civilization itself. It also absorbs heat, making the world cold. Peace is expensive. War is productive. Some people are worth more dead than alive, and everyone knows the math. 40,000-50,000 years ago, Hálcova was warmer. Something changed it. Ancient structures at both poles hint at deliberate engineering. The five moons orbit in suspiciously perfect resonance. Whoever built the world's systems is gone, but their work persists. This wiki collects all major aspects of the world, including its Metaphysics , Magic Systems , Fate System , Society , Governance , Planetary details, and Conlang . Use the sidebar to explore each section. The Metaphysical Spine Hálcova isn't a world with an economy—it is an economy. Economic and psychological principles are the literal physics of reality here. See more in Metaphysics . At what point are you no longer you? Experience Machine : The Elsewhere offers unlimited sensation. Why not accept? Planetary Parameters Geography, climate, and moons are covered in Planetary . The sky is teal-tinged blue. Sunsets linger in deep amber and blood red. Vegetation evolved dark to absorb available light—black polar, purple-red temperate, red-orange tropical. Auroras are extreme and correlate with Pattern Residue concentration. The Five Moons Each moon corresponds to a Sórscad circle and a magical practice. The orbital resonances are too perfect to be natural—someone arranged them. Death, endurance, debt settlement. Olvadás (Thaw): Dangerous transition, 76 days. Disease, opportunity. Láng (Flame): High summer, 77 days. Conflict, harvest, fate's height. Hanyatlás (Decline): Urgent preparation, 76 days. Last chances. Köd (Veil): Strange season, 45-46 days. Elsewhere bleed at the poles. docs.title: World Summary

docs.text: Hálcova (HAHL-ko-vah) — "The Death-Between" — is a dark fantasy ice world orbiting an orange dwarf star. Every person carries a Sórscad , a five-part fate pattern that determines who they are and what they'll become. Something answers when this pattern is read. That something may be divine, may be Elsewhere, may be both. Nobody knows for certain. The world runs on death. Pattern Residue — the energy released when fates dissolve — fuels Magic Systems , industry, and civilization itself. It also absorbs heat, making the world cold. Peace is expensive. War is productive. Some people are worth more dead than alive, and everyone knows the math. 40,000-50,000 years ago, Hálcova was warmer. Something changed it. Ancient structures at both poles hint at deliberate engineering. The five moons orbit in suspiciously perfect resonance. Whoever built the world's systems is gone, but their work persists. This wiki collects all major aspects of the world, including its Metaphysics , Magic Systems , Fate System , Society , Governance , Planetary details, and Conlang . Use the sidebar to explore each section.

docs.text: Sárgvas casts amber-gold light. The sky is teal-tinged blue. Sunsets linger in deep amber and blood red. Vegetation evolved dark to absorb available light—black polar, purple-red temperate, red-orange tropical. Auroras are extreme and correlate with Pattern Residue concentration.
docs.title: The Star and Sky

docs.text: Each moon corresponds to a Sórscad circle and a magical practice. The orbital resonances are too perfect to be natural—someone arranged them. Moon Association Character Lélek Soul/Core Binding Largest, pale gold Hús Flesh/Flesh Shaping Medium, reddish Kötel Binding/Pact Summoning Medium, dim grey Vég Death/Colony Summoning Small, bright white Fonál Fate/Fate Threading Smallest, distant
docs.title: The Five Moons

docs.text: Csend (Silence): Deep winter, 76 days. Death, endurance, debt settlement. Olvadás (Thaw): Dangerous transition, 76 days. Disease, opportunity. Láng (Flame): High summer, 77 days. Conflict, harvest, fate's height. Hanyatlás (Decline): Urgent preparation, 76 days. Last chances. Köd (Veil): Strange season, 45-46 days. Elsewhere bleed at the poles.
